sols_html:
Note that every non-zero vector in \(\mathbb{R}^2\) is an eigenvector for T (corresponding to the eigenvalue 5).

In particular, the standard basis \(\{\begin{pmatrix}1\\0\end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 0\\1\end{pmatrix}\}\) is a basis of \(\mathbb{R}^2\) consisting of eigenvectors of T.

statement_html: Let \(T: \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2\) be the linear map given by \(T(v) = 5v\), for all \(v \in \mathbb{R}^2\) (T is a dilation). Find a basis of \(\mathbb{R}^2\) consisting of eigenvalues of T, or explain why this is not possible.
